SENT.plain: We selected, reanalyzed, and compared data from current prevalence studies of vascular dementia in Europe

Inclusion criteria were: dementia defined by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual for Mental Disorders, edition 3, or equivalent criteria; case finding through direct individual examination; appropriate sample size; and inclusion of institutionalized persons
Mixed dementia was combined with vascular dementia
Of the 23 surveys of dementia considered, five fulfilled the inclusion criteria
Age-specific prevalence varied more widely for men than for women; differences were greater in older ages
The prevalence increased steeply with advancing age in all countries, and was generally higher in men; it declined over 15 years in the age class of 80 to 89 years in one Swedish population
Within populations, Alzheimer's disease was generally more common than vascular dementia
Unfortunately, prevalence studies of vascular dementia are limited in Europe and worldwide, and their comparison is impeded by the lack of common diagnostic criteria
